sen.j: 雄略天皇（ゆうりゃくてんのう、允恭天皇7年（418年）12月 (旧暦) - 雄略天皇23年8月7日 (旧暦)（479年9月8日））は、第21代の天皇（在位：安康天皇3年11月13日 (旧暦)（456年12月25日） - 雄略天皇23年8月7日（479年9月8日））。
sen.e: Emperor Yuryaku (January 419 – September 9, 479; reign: December 26, 456 – September 9, 479) was the twenty-first emperor of Japan.
Emperor Yuryaku (January 419 – September 9, 479; reign: December 26, 456 – September 9, 479) was the twenty-first emperor of Japan.
Emperor Yuryaku (January 419 – September 9, 479; reign: December 26, 456 – September 9, 479) was the twenty-first emperor of Japan.

sen.j: 大泊瀬幼武尊（おおはつせわかたけるのみこと）、大長谷若建命・大長谷王（古事記）。
sen.e: He was also called Ohatsusewakatakeru no mikoto (大泊瀬幼武尊); and according to the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), his name was also expressed as Ohatsusewakatakeru no mikoto (大長谷若建命) and Ohatsuse no miko.
sen.cmt: 同じ読みで違う漢字が出ているので、そのまま訳出しています。
sen.e: He was also called Ohatsusewakatakeru no mikoto (大泊瀬幼武尊); and according to the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), his name was also expressed as Ohatsusewakatakeru no mikoto (大長谷若建命) and Ohatsuse no miko.

He was also called Ohatsusewakatakeru no mikoto (大泊瀬幼武尊); and according to the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), his name was also expressed as Ohatsusewakatakeru no mikoto (大長谷若建命) and Ohatsuse no miko.

sen.j: 大悪天皇・有徳天皇とも。
sen.e: He is also described as the Evil Emperor and the Virtuous Emperor.
He is also described as the Evil Emperor and the Virtuous Emperor.
He is also described as the Evil Emperor and the Virtuous Emperor.

sen.j: また『宋書』・『梁書』に記される「倭の五王」中の倭王武に比定される。
sen.e: He is identified with Waobu (the last king of ancient Japan) among the 'five kings of Wa,' described in the "Sungshu" (Book of the Sung dynasty) and the "Liangshu" (Book of the Liang dynasty).
He is identified with Waobu (the last king of ancient Japan) among the 'five kings of Wa,' described in the "Sungshu" (Book of the Sung dynasty) and the "Liangshu" (Book of the Liang dynasty).
He is identified with Waobu (the last king of ancient Japan) among the 'five kings of Wa,' described in the "Sungshu" (Book of the Sung dynasty) and the "Liangshu" (Book of the Liang dynasty).

sen.j: 倭王武の上表文には周辺諸国を攻略して勢力を拡張した様子が表現されている。
sen.e: In the Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor) of Waobu, there is a description of how the king invaded the nearby countries and became a major power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor) of Waobu, there is a description of how the king invaded the nearby countries and became a major power.
In the Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor) of Waobu, there is a description of how the king invaded the nearby countries and became a major power.

sen.j: 熊本県玉名郡和水町の江田船山古墳出土の銀象嵌鉄刀銘や埼玉県行田市の稲荷山古墳出土の金錯銘鉄剣銘を「獲加多支鹵大王 (ヤマト王権)」と解しその証とする説が有力である。
sen.e: Also there is a popular theory to prove his power by deciphering the inscriptions on iron sword inlaid with silver (excavated from the Eta Funayama Tumulus [Nagomi Town, Tamana County, Kumamoto Prefecture]) and iron sword with gold inscription (excavated from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus [Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture]) as 'Wakatakeru no Okimi (the Great King Wakatakeru).'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処；（ヤマト王権）とあるのはリンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると（ワカタケル大王）となっているので、これで訳出しています。
sen.e: Also there is a popular theory to prove his power by deciphering the inscriptions on the iron sword inlaid with silver (excavated from the Eta Funayama Tumulus (Nagomi Town, Tamana County, Kumamoto Prefecture)) and the iron sword with gold inscription (excavated from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus (Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture)) as 'Wakatakeru no Okimi (the Great King Wakatakeru).'
sen.cmt: iron sword に定冠詞(the)を付与。鍵括弧を小括弧に変更。
sen.e: Also there is a popular theory to prove his power by deciphering the inscriptions on the iron sword inlaid with silver (excavated from the Eta Funayama Tumulus (Nagomi Town, Tamana County, Kumamoto Prefecture)) and the iron sword with gold inscription (excavated from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus (Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture)) as 'Wakatakeru no Okimi (the Great King Wakatakeru).'

sen.j: この説に則れば考古学的に実在が実証される最古の天皇である。
sen.e: According to this theory, he is the oldest emperor whose existence is archaeologically proven.
According to this theory, he is the oldest emperor whose existence is archaeologically proven.
According to this theory, he is the oldest emperor whose existence is archaeologically proven.

sen.j: 朝廷としての組織は未熟であったが、『日本書紀』の暦法が雄略紀以降とそれ以前で異なること、『万葉集』や『日本現報善悪霊異記』の冒頭に雄略天皇が掲げられていることから、古代の人々が雄略朝を歴史的な画期として捉えていたとみることもできる。
sen.e: His governance was not perfect, but we can suppose that ancient people regarded his reign as a historical epoch from the following facts: before and after the Yuryaku period, the calendar of the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) changes; and the Emperor Yuryaku appears in the beginning parts of "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the Nihon Ryoiki).

His governance was not perfect, but we can suppose that ancient people regarded his reign as a historical epoch from the following facts: before and after the Yuryaku period, the calendar of the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) changes; and the Emperor Yuryaku appears in the beginning parts of "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the Nihon Ryoiki).

His governance was not perfect, but we can suppose that ancient people regarded his reign as a historical epoch from the following facts: before and after the Yuryaku period, the calendar of the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) changes; and the Emperor Yuryaku appears in the beginning parts of "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the Nihon Ryoiki).

sen.j: 皇居
sen.e: Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace

sen.j: 都は初瀬朝倉宮（はつせのあさくらのみや）。
sen.e: The Imperial palace was Hatsuse no Asakura no Miya Palace.
The Imperial palace was Hatsuse no Asakura no Miya Palace.
The Imperial palace was Hatsuse no Asakura no Miya Palace.

sen.j: 稲荷山古墳出土金象嵌鉄剣銘に見える「斯鬼宮（しきのみや ・磯城宮）」も朝倉宮を指すと言われる（別に河内の志紀（大阪府八尾市）とする説もある）。
sen.e: The inscription 'Shikinomiya Palace' (described as 斯鬼宮or 磯城宮) on the iron sword inlaid with gold from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus is supposed to indicate Asakura no Miya Palace (yet there is another theory to regard this as Shiki [志紀] in Kawachi region [Yao City, Osaka Prefecture]).
sen.cmt: 同じ読みに対して別の漢字が表記されているので、そのまま出しています。
sen.e: The inscription 'Shikinomiya Palace' (described as 斯鬼宮or 磯城宮) on the iron sword inlaid with gold from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus is supposed to indicate Asakura no Miya Palace (yet there is another theory to regard this as Shiki (志紀) in Kawachi region (Yao City, Osaka Prefecture)).
sen.cmt: 鍵括弧を小括弧に変更。
sen.e: The inscription 'Shikinomiya Palace' (described as 斯鬼宮or 磯城宮) on the iron sword inlaid with gold from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus is supposed to indicate Asakura no Miya Palace (yet there is another theory to regard this as Shiki (志紀) in Kawachi region (Yao City, Osaka Prefecture)).

sen.j: 伝承地は奈良県桜井市黒崎（一説に岩坂）である。
sen.e: Generally the site is considered to be today's Kurozaki (other records say Iwasaka) in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Generally the site is considered to be today's Kurozaki (another theory says Iwasaka) in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一説をother recordsからanother theoryに変更
sen.e: Generally the site is considered to be today's Kurozaki (another theory says Iwasaka) in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: しかし1984年、同市脇本にある脇本遺跡から、5世紀後半のものと推定される掘立柱穴が発見された。
sen.e: However, in 1984, a pit of a pillar embedded directly in the ground was found in the Wakimoto ruins located at Wakimoto, Sakurai City, and it was supposed to date back to the late 5th century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in 1984, a pit of a pillar embedded directly in the ground was found in the Wakimoto ruins located at Wakimoto, Sakurai City, and it was supposed to date back to the late 5th century.
However, in 1984, a pit of a pillar embedded directly in the ground was found in the Wakimoto ruins located at Wakimoto, Sakurai City, and it was supposed to date back to the late 5th century.

sen.j: 朝倉宮の跡とされ話題を呼んだ。
sen.e: It attracted people's attention as it was considered to be the site of the Asakura no Miya Palace.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It attracted people's attention as it was considered to be the site of the Asakura no Miya Palace.
It attracted people's attention as it was considered to be the site of the Asakura no Miya Palace.

sen.j: これ以降一定期間、初瀬に皇居があったと唱える人もいる。
sen.e: Some say that the Palace was moved to Hatsuse afterwards.
Some say that the Palace was moved to Hatsuse afterwards for a certain period.
sen.cmt: for a certain period(一定期間)を追加
sen.e: Some say that the Palace was moved to Hatsuse afterwards for a certain period.

sen.j: 尚、『日本現報善悪霊異記』によれば、磐余宮（いわれのみや）にも居たという。
sen.e: According to "Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki", the Emperor was also in the Iware no Miya Palace.
According to the Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki, the Emperor was also in the Iware no Miya Palace.
sen.cmt: “Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki”からthe Nihon genho Zenaku ryoikiに変更（既出なので）。
sen.e: According to the Nihon genho Zenaku ryoiki, the Emperor was also in the Iware no Miya Palace.

sen.j: 記紀によれば安康天皇3年（456年）8月、安康天皇が幼年の眉輪王（まよわのおおきみ、古事記では7歳）により暗殺されたという。
sen.e: The Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki say that the Emperor Anko was murdered in September 456 by Prince Mayowa, who was still young (seven years old, according to the Kojiki).
The Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki say that the Emperor Anko was assassinated in September 456 by Prince Mayowa, who was still young (seven years old, according to the Kojiki).
The Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki say that the Emperor Anko was assassinated in September 456 by Prince Mayowa, who was still young (seven years old, according to the Kojiki).

sen.j: これを知った大泊瀬皇子は兄たちを疑った。
sen.e: When Prince Ohatsuse learned this, he suspected his older brothers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Prince Ohatsuse learned this, he suspected his older brothers.
When Prince Ohatsuse learned this, he suspected his older brothers.

sen.j: まず八釣白彦皇子を斬り殺し、次いで坂合黒彦皇子 ・眉輪王をも殺そうとした。
sen.e: He murdered Prince Yatsurishirohiko first, and then planned to murder Prince Sakai no Kurohiko and Prince Mayowa.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He killed Prince Yatsurishirohiko with a sword first, and then planned to kill Prince Sakai no Kurohiko and Prince Mayowa.
sen.cmt: 斬り殺すをkill with a swordと訳出し
sen.e: He killed Prince Yatsurishirohiko with a sword first, and then planned to kill Prince Sakai no Kurohiko and Prince Mayowa.

sen.j: この2人は相談して葛城氏の円大臣（つぶらのおおおみ）宅に逃げ込んだ。
sen.e: These two princes talked over how to deal with this, and took sanctuary in the residence of Tsubura no Oomi, a member of the Katsuragi clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These two princes talked over how to deal with this, and took sanctuary in the residence of Tsubura no Oomi, a member of the Katsuragi clan.
These two princes talked over how to deal with this, and took sanctuary in the residence of Tsubura no Oomi, a member of the Katsuragi clan.

sen.j: 大臣の助命嘆願も空しく、大泊瀬皇子は3人共に焼き殺してしまう。
sen.e: Oomi begged their lives, but Prince Ohatsuse set fire on them and killed all three.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Oomi begged their lives, but Prince Ohatsuse set fire on them and killed all three.
Oomi begged their lives, but Prince Ohatsuse set fire on them and killed all three.

sen.j: さらに、市辺押磐皇子（いちのへのおしはのみこ、仁賢天皇 ・顕宗天皇の父）とその弟の御馬皇子（みまのみこ）をも謀殺した。
sen.e: In addition, he murdered Prince Ichinohe no Oshihano (father of the Emperor Ninken and the Emperor Kenzo) and his younger brother Prince Mima.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, he murdered Prince Ichinohe no Oshihano (father of the Emperor Ninken and the Emperor Kenzo) and his younger brother Prince Mima.
In addition, he murdered Prince Ichinohe no Oshihano (father of the Emperor Ninken and the Emperor Kenzo) and his younger brother Prince Mima.

sen.j: 政敵を一掃して11月 (旧暦)に大王の座に就いた。
sen.e: Thus he swept all political opponents and became an emperor in December.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus he swept all political opponents and became the emperor in December.
Thus he swept all political opponents and became the emperor in December.

sen.j: 即位後も人を処刑することが多かった。
sen.e: Even after accession, he often ordered execution.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Even after the accession, he often ordered executions.
sen.cmt: accessionに冠詞theを付与、executionを複数形に変更
sen.e: Even after the accession, he often ordered executions.

sen.j: そのため後に大悪天皇と誹謗される原因となっている。
sen.e: That is why he is later abused as the Evil Emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: That is why he was later abused as the Evil Emperor.
That is why he was later abused as the Evil Emperor.

sen.j: しかし大悪天皇の記述は武烈天皇にも見られることから両者は同一人物ではないかとの説もある。
sen.e: However, as the Emperor Buretsu is also described as the Evil Emperor, there is a theory that says these two emperors are the same person.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, as the Emperor Buretsu is also described as the Evil Emperor, there is a theory that says these two emperors were the same person.
However, as the Emperor Buretsu is also described as the Evil Emperor, there is a theory that says these two emperors were the same person.

sen.j: 平群真鳥（へぐりのまとり）を大臣に、大伴室屋（おおとものむろや）・物部目（もののべのめ）を大連（おおむらじ）に任じて、軍事力で専制王権を確立した大泊瀬幼武大王（雄略天皇）。
sen.e: By appointing HEGURI no Matori as an Oomi, and OTOMO no Muroya and MONONOBE no Me as Omuraji (Oomi and Omuraji are high ranking titles), Ohatsuse no Wakatakeru no Okimi (the Emperor Yuryaku) established a tyrannical government with military power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処；大臣と大連の説明を挿入しています。
sen.e: By appointing HEGURI no Matori as an Oomi, and OTOMO no Muroya and MONONOBE no Me as Omuraji (Oomi and Omuraji are high ranking titles), Ohatsuse no Wakatakeru no Okimi (the Emperor Yuryaku) established a tyrannical government with military power.

By appointing HEGURI no Matori as an Oomi, and OTOMO no Muroya and MONONOBE no Me as Omuraji (Oomi and Omuraji are high ranking titles), Ohatsuse no Wakatakeru no Okimi (the Emperor Yuryaku) established a tyrannical government with military power.

sen.j: その次の狙いは、連合的に結び付いていた地域国家を大和政権に臣従させることであった。
sen.e: His next aim was to submit the alliance of local states to the Yamato Administration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His next aim was to submit the alliance of local states to the Yamato Administration.
His next aim was to submit the alliance of local states to the Yamato Administration.

sen.j: 特に最大の地域政権吉備国に対して反乱鎮圧の名目で屈服を迫った（吉備氏の乱）。
sen.e: With good reason of rebellion suppression (KIBI Clan disturbance), he urged the Kibi Province, the largest local state, to submit.
With good reason of rebellion suppression (KIBI Clan disturbance), he urged the Kibi Province, the largest local state, to submit.
With good reason of rebellion suppression (KIBI Clan disturbance), he urged the Kibi Province, the largest local state, to submit.

sen.j: 具体的には、吉備下道臣前津屋（きびのしもつみちのおみさきつや ・463年）や吉備田狭（きびのかみつみちのおみたさ ・463年）の「反乱」を討伐して吉備政権の弱体化を進めた。
sen.e: To be specific, he weakened the power of the Kibi government by subjugating the "rebellions" of KIBI no Shimotsumichi no Omisakitsuya (463) and of KIBI no Kamitsumichi no omi Tasa (463).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処；本文に「吉備田狭」とあるのはリンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると吉備上道臣田狭となっているので、これで訳出しました。
sen.e: To be specific, he weakened the power of the Kibi government by subjugating the "rebellions" of KIBI no Shimotsumichi no Omisakitsuya (463) and of KIBI no Kamitsumichi no omi Tasa (463).
To be specific, he weakened the power of the Kibi government by subjugating the "rebellions" of KIBI no Shimotsumichi no Omisakitsuya (463) and of KIBI no Kamitsumichi no omi Tasa (463).

sen.j: さらに雄略天皇の崩後に起こった星川稚宮皇子（母が吉備稚媛）の乱を大伴室屋らが鎮圧して（479年）、大和政権の優位を決定的にした。
sen.e: In addition, after the Emperor Yuryaku's death, OTOMO no Muroya and others subjugated the rebellion of Hoshikawa no Wakamiya no miko (a son of KIBI no Wakahime) in 479 and achieved the dominance of the Yamato Administration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, after the Emperor Yuryaku's death, OTOMO no Muroya and others subjugated the rebellion of Hoshikawa no Wakamiya no miko (a son of KIBI no Wakahime) in 479 and achieved the dominance of the Yamato Administration.

In addition, after the Emperor Yuryaku's death, OTOMO no Muroya and others subjugated the rebellion of Hoshikawa no Wakamiya no miko (a son of KIBI no Wakahime) in 479 and achieved the dominance of the Yamato Administration.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』には他に、播磨国の文石小麻呂（あやしのおまろ・469年）や伊勢国の朝日郎（あさけのいらつこ・474年）を討伐した記事が見えている。
sen.e: The "Nihon Shoki" also describe that the Emperor subjugated other rebellions, such as that of AYASHI no Omaro in the Harima Province (469) and ASAKE no Iratsuko in the Ise Province (474).
The Nihon Shoki also describes that the Emperor subjugated other rebellions, such as that of AYASHI no Omaro in the Harima Province (469) and ASAKE no Iratsuko in the Ise Province (474).
sen.cmt: The “Nihon Shoki”をThe Nihon Shokiに変更、describe をdescribesに変更
sen.e: The Nihon Shoki also describes that the Emperor subjugated other rebellions, such as that of AYASHI no Omaro in the Harima Province (469) and ASAKE no Iratsuko in the Ise Province (474).

sen.j: 対外関係では、雄略天皇8年2月（464年）に任那日本府軍が高句麗を破り、9年5月には新羅に攻め込んだ。
sen.e: Outside Japan, the Japanese Mimana Governmental Army defeated Goguryeo in February 464, and invaded Silla in June 465.
Outside Japan, the Japanese Mimana Governmental Army defeated Goguryeo in February 464, and invaded Silla in June 465.
Outside Japan, the Japanese Mimana Governmental Army defeated Goguryeo in February 464, and invaded Silla in June 465.

sen.j: しかし将軍の紀小弓宿禰（きのおゆみのすくね）が戦死し、敗走したと言う。
sen.e: However, the general KI no Oyumi no Sukune was killed in the battle and the army retreated.
However, it was said that General KI no Oyumi no Sukune was killed in the battle and the army retreated.
sen.cmt: it was said thatを追加、the general をGeneral に変更
sen.e: However, it was said that General KI no Oyumi no Sukune was killed in the battle and the army retreated.

sen.j: （『三国史記』新羅本紀によれば倭が462年5月に新羅の活開城を攻め落とし、463年2月にも侵入したが、最終的に新羅が打ち破ったと記載されている）。
sen.e: (According to the "Samguk Sagi" [History of the Three Kingdoms] Silla History, Wa had 活開城 surrendered in May 464 and invaded again in February 463, but finally Silla beat Wa.)
(According to the "Samguk Sagi" (History of the Three Kingdoms) Silla History, Wa had 活開城 surrendered in May 464 and invaded again in February 463, but finally Silla beat Wa).
sen.cmt: 鍵括弧を小括弧に変更、ピリオドを右括弧の外に出した。
sen.e: (According to the "Samguk Sagi" (History of the Three Kingdoms) Silla History, Wa had 活開城 surrendered in May 464 and invaded again in February 463, but finally Silla beat Wa).

sen.j: 20年（476年）に高句麗が百済を攻め滅ぼしたが、翌21年（477年）、大王は百済に任那を与えて復興したという（『三国史記』高句麗本紀・百済本紀によれば、475年9月に高句麗に都を攻め落とされ王は殺され、同年熊津に遷都している）。
sen.e: Records say that Goguryeo beat Baekje in 476, and that the Emperor gave Mimana to Baekje in order to help its reconstruction in 477 (According to the "Samguk Sagi" History of Goguryeo and History of Baekje, Baekje surrendered the capital to Goguryeo in September 475, had the king killed, and moved its capital to Ungjin during the same year).

Records say that Goguryeo beat Baekje in 476, and that the Emperor gave Mimana to Baekje in order to help its reconstruction in 477 (according to the "Samguk Sagi" History of Goguryeo and History of Baekje, Baekje surrendered the capital to Goguryeo in September 475, had the king killed, and moved its capital to Ungjin during the same year).
sen.cmt: 括弧の中のAccording をaccordingに変更
sen.e: Records say that Goguryeo beat Baekje in 476, and that the Emperor gave Mimana to Baekje in order to help its reconstruction in 477 (according to the "Samguk Sagi" History of Goguryeo and History of Baekje, Baekje surrendered the capital to Goguryeo in September 475, had the king killed, and moved its capital to Ungjin during the same year).

sen.j: この他、呉国（宋 (南朝)）から手工業者・漢織（あやはとり）・呉織（くれはとり）らを招き、また、分散していた秦民（秦氏の民）の統率を強化して、養蚕業を奨励したことも知られる。
sen.e: Emperor Yuryaku is also known for having promoted the sericultural industry by inviting handicraftsmen such as Ayahatori and Kurehartori from Wu (Sung [Southern Dynasty]) and by gathering and controlling scattered people of the Hata clan.

Emperor Yuryaku is also known for having promoted the sericultural industry by inviting handicraftsmen such as Ayahatori and Kurehartori from Wu (Sung (Southern Dynasty)) and by gathering and controlling scattered people of the Hata clan.
sen.cmt: 鍵括弧を小括弧に変更
sen.e: Emperor Yuryaku is also known for having promoted the sericultural industry by inviting handicraftsmen such as Ayahatori and Kurehartori from Wu (Sung (Southern Dynasty)) and by gathering and controlling scattered people of the Hata clan.

sen.j: 479年4月、百済の三斤王が亡くなると、入質していた昆支王の次子未多王に筑紫の兵500をつけて帰国させ、東城王として即位させた。
sen.e: In April 479, when the Emperor learned the death of Samgeun of Baekje, he let the hostage Mata O (the second son of Konki O) go home with 500 warriors of Chikushi region, and had him succeed to the throne as Dongseong of Baekje.
sen.cmt: 「未多王」はウェブ上もこの表記になっていますが、「末多王」（またおう）の誤りと思われます。
sen.e: In April 479, when the Emperor learned the death of Samgeun of Baekje, he let the hostage Mata O (the second son of Konki O) go home with 500 warriors of Chikushi region, and had him succeed to the throne as Dongseong of Baekje.

In April 479, when the Emperor learned the death of Samgeun of Baekje, he let the hostage Mata O (the second son of Konki O) go home with 500 warriors of Chikushi region, and had him succeed to the throne as Dongseong of Baekje.

sen.j: 兵を率いた安致臣・馬飼臣らは水軍を率いて高句麗を討った。
sen.e: Achi no Omi and Umakai no Omi led Suigun (warriors battle in the sea) and defeated Goguryeo.
Achi no Omi and Umakai no Omi led Suigun (warriors who battle in the sea) and defeated Goguryeo.
sen.cmt: 「水軍」をwarriors who battle in the seaと訳出し
sen.e: Achi no Omi and Umakai no Omi led Suigun (warriors who battle in the sea) and defeated Goguryeo.

sen.j: 22年（478年）白髪皇子(後の清寧天皇)を皇太子とした。
sen.e: In 478, the Emperor designated the Prince Shiraka (later the Emperor Seinei) as the Crown Prince.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 478, the Emperor designated the Prince Shiraka (later the Emperor Seinei) as the Crown Prince.
In 478, the Emperor designated the Prince Shiraka (later the Emperor Seinei) as the Crown Prince.

sen.j: 翌23年（479年）8月、大王は病気のため崩御した。
sen.e: In September 479, the Emperor died of an illness.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In September 479, the Emperor died of an illness.
In September 479, the Emperor died of an illness.

sen.j: 梁書によると、梁の武帝は502年、雄略天皇に比定される倭王武を征東将軍に進号した。
sen.e: According to the Liangshu, Wu Di of Liang gave the title of Seito Shogun (great general who subdues the eastern barbarians) to Waobu, who is identified as the Emperor Yuryaku, in 502.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the Liangshu, Wu Di of Liang gave the title of Seito Shogun (great general who subdues the eastern barbarians) to Waobu, who is identified as the Emperor Yuryaku, in 502.
According to the Liangshu, Wu Di of Liang gave the title of Seito Shogun (great general who subdues the eastern barbarians) to Waobu, who is identified as the Emperor Yuryaku, in 502.

sen.j: このことから、この年に遣使自体は行われなかったものの実際の没年は記紀による年代よりも後であった可能性もある。
sen.e: From this description, it can be said that the year of death of the Emperor Yuryaku was later than that shown in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki, although no envoy was dispatched to Liang in 502.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From this description, it can be said that the year of death of the Emperor Yuryaku was later than that shown in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki, although no envoy was dispatched to Liang in 502.
From this description, it can be said that the year of death of the Emperor Yuryaku was later than that shown in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki, although no envoy was dispatched to Liang in 502.

sen.j: 雄略天皇の血筋は男系では途切れている。
sen.e: The genealogy of the Emperor Yuryaku through male family does not continue.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The genealogy of the Emperor Yuryaku through male family does not continue.
The genealogy of the Emperor Yuryaku through male family does not continue.

sen.j: しかし皇女の春日大娘皇女が仁賢天皇の皇后となり、その娘の手白香皇女が継体天皇の皇后となり欽明天皇を産んでいる。
sen.e: However, his daughter Kasuga no Oiratsume no Himemiko became the empress to the Emperor Ninken, and her daughter Tashiraka no Himemko became the empress to the Emperor Keitai and gave birth to the Emperor Kinmei.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, his daughter Kasuga no Oiratsume no Himemiko became the empress to the Emperor Ninken, and her daughter Tashiraka no Himemko became the empress to the Emperor Keitai and gave birth to the Emperor Kinmei.

However, his daughter Kasuga no Oiratsume no Himemiko became the empress to the Emperor Ninken, and her daughter Tashiraka no Himemko became the empress to the Emperor Keitai and gave birth to the Emperor Kinmei.

sen.j: このことから、その血筋は現在まで続く事となった。
sen.e: Therefore, the genealogy of the Emperor has been continuing up to now.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the genealogy of the Emperor has been continuing up to now.
Therefore, the genealogy of the Emperor has been continuing up to now.

sen.j: 丹比高鷲原陵（たじひのたかわしのはらのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was buried in Tajihi no Takawashi no Hara Mausoleum.
The Emperor was buried in Tajihi no Takawashi no Hara Mausoleum.
The Emperor was buried in Tajihi no Takawashi no Hara Mausoleum.

sen.j: 大阪府羽曳野市島泉にある高鷲丸山古墳（古墳古墳の形式一覧・径76m・島泉丸山古墳とも）と平塚古墳（方墳・辺50m）に比定されている。
sen.e: It is identified with the Takawashi Maruyama Tumulus (a round barrow; 76m in diameter; also called the Shimaizumi Maruyama Tumulus) and the Hiratsuka Tumulus (square tumulus; the side 50m) in Shimaizumi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 原文で「古墳古墳の形式一覧」となっているところは、ウェブで確認すると「円墳」となっているので、これで訳出しました。
sen.e: It is identified with the Takawashi Maruyama Tumulus (a round barrow; 76m in diameter; also called the Shimaizumi Maruyama Tumulus) and the Hiratsuka Tumulus (square tumulus; 50m per side) in Shimaizumi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture.

It is identified with the Takawashi Maruyama Tumulus (a round barrow; 76m in diameter; also called the Shimaizumi Maruyama Tumulus) and the Hiratsuka Tumulus (square tumulus; 50m per side) in Shimaizumi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture.

sen.j: 近年一部の考古学者が、同県松原市西大塚と羽曳野市南恵我之荘に亘る河内大塚山古墳（前方後円墳・全長335m）とする説がある。
sen.e: Recently some archaeologists advocated that the Mausoleum was the Otsukayama Tumulus (a keyhole-shaped mound; 335m in length) stretching over Nishiotsuka, Matsubara City, Osaka Prefecture and Minami-eganoso, Habikino City.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Recently some archaeologists advocated that the Mausoleum was the Otsukayama Tumulus (a keyhole-shaped mound; 335m in length) stretching over Nishiotsuka, Matsubara City, Osaka Prefecture and Minami-eganoso, Habikino City.

Recently some archaeologists advocated that the Mausoleum was the Otsukayama Tumulus (a keyhole-shaped mound; 335m in length) stretching over Nishiotsuka, Matsubara City, Osaka Prefecture and Minami-eganoso, Habikino City.

sen.j: 陵墓参考地のために詳細な調査がなされておらず不明確な点があるものの、埴輪の存在が明らかでないなどの特徴から、前方後円墳終末期のものであるとの説が強い。
sen.e: This mausoleum is generally supposed to have been constructed as one of the last keyhole-shaped mounds judging from the fact that it does not furnish Haniwa (unglazed terra-cotta cylinders and hollow sculptures arranged on and around the mounded tombs [kofun]), although no detailed investigation has been carried out because this is just a referable mausoleum.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This mausoleum is generally supposed to have been constructed as one of the last keyhole-shaped mounds judging from the fact that it does not furnish Haniwa (unglazed terra-cotta cylinders and hollow sculptures arranged on and around the mounded tombs (kofun)), although no detailed investigation has been carried out because this is just a referable mausoleum.
sen.cmt: 鍵括弧を小括弧に変更
sen.e: This mausoleum is generally supposed to have been constructed as one of the last keyhole-shaped mounds judging from the fact that it does not furnish Haniwa (unglazed terra-cotta cylinders and hollow sculptures arranged on and around the mounded tombs (kofun)), although no detailed investigation has been carried out because this is just a referable mausoleum.

sen.j: そうすると雄略の崩年と築造年代に数十年の開きがあり妥当なものではない。
sen.e: If the supposition is true, this Otsukayama theory is not reasonable because the construction period and the death year of Yuryaku have several decades of difference.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If the supposition is true, this Otsukayama theory is not reasonable because the construction period and the death year of Yuryaku have several decades of difference.
If the supposition is true, this Otsukayama theory is not reasonable because the construction period and the death year of Yuryaku have several decades of difference.

sen.j: 『古事記』によると、顕宗天皇の父（市辺押磐皇子）の仇討ちをすべく、意祁命（後の仁賢天皇）自ら雄略天皇陵の墳丘の一部を小規模ながら破壊した、とある。
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki," Oke no mikoto (later the Emperor Ninken) himself destroyed a part of the tumulus of the Emperor Yuryaku in order to inflict vengeance for the father of the Emperor Kenzo (Prince Ichihe no Oshihano).

According to the Kojiki, Oke no mikoto (later the Emperor Ninken) himself destroyed a part of the tumulus of the Emperor Yuryaku in order to inflict vengeance for the father of the Emperor Kenzo (Prince Ichihe no Oshihano).

According to the Kojiki, Oke no mikoto (later the Emperor Ninken) himself destroyed a part of the tumulus of the Emperor Yuryaku in order to inflict vengeance for the father of the Emperor Kenzo (Prince Ichihe no Oshihano).

sen.j: 『書紀』にも顕宗が陵破壊を提案したとあるが、皇太子億計がこれを諌めて思い止まらせたとする。
sen.e: In the "Nihon Shoki," there is a description that Kenzo suggested the destruction of the tumulus, but that the Prince Oke remonstrated and dissuaded him from doing that.
In the Nihon Shoki, there is a description that Kenzo suggested the destruction of the tumulus, but that the Prince Oke remonstrated and dissuaded him from doing that.
In the Nihon Shoki, there is a description that Kenzo suggested the destruction of the tumulus, but that the Prince Oke remonstrated and dissuaded him from doing that.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮外宮を建立。
sen.e: He had the Geku (the outer shrine) of the Ise-jinja Shrine constructed.
He had the Geku (the outer shrine) of the Ise-jinja Shrine constructed.
He had the Geku (the outer shrine) of the Ise-jinja Shrine constructed.

sen.j: 元々、豊受大神は葛城氏が代表して奉祀していた。
sen.e: Originally, Toyouke no Okami (Grand Divine Toyouke) had been enshrined by the Katsuragi clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Originally, Toyouke no Okami (Grand Divine Toyouke) had been enshrined by the Katsuragi clan.
Originally, Toyouke no Okami (Grand Divine Toyouke) had been enshrined by the Katsuragi clan.

sen.j: 葛城氏没落後、あまり省みられなかった。
sen.e: After the downfall of the Katsuragi clan, the ritual had not been conducted very well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the downfall of the Katsuragi clan, the ritual had not been conducted very well.
After the downfall of the Katsuragi clan, the ritual had not been conducted very well.

sen.j: 崇敬の声が大きくなり、丹波国にも祀られていたものを、雄略天皇22年（崩御前年）に外宮を設立することで収拾を図ったのではないかとする説がある。
sen.e: Following the movement of worship, the Emperor had the Geku constructed in 478 (one year before his death), also with another aim that is to enshrine the Divine which had also been enshrined in the Tanba Province, a theory says.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Following the movement of worship, the Emperor had the Geku constructed in 478 (one year before his death), also with another aim to enshrine the Divine which had also been enshrined in the Tanba Province, a theory says.
sen.cmt: that is to enshrine を to enshrineに変更
sen.e: Following the movement of worship, the Emperor had the Geku constructed in 478 (one year before his death), also with another aim to enshrine the Divine which had also been enshrined in the Tanba Province, a theory says.

sen.j: 豊受大神と名が似ている飯豊天皇は、その揺り返しの中で政務を執った可能性もある。
sen.e: It might have been under this movement that the Emperor Iitoyo, who has a similar name to the Toyouke no Okami, took the governance.
It might have been under this movement that the Emperor Iitoyo, who has a similar name to the Toyouke no Okami, took the governance.
It might have been under this movement that the Emperor Iitoyo, who has a similar name to the Toyouke no Okami, took the governance.

sen.j: また、雄略天皇の皇女で、斎宮である栲幡姫皇女（稚足姫皇女）が、湯人（ゆえ：皇子女の沐浴等に仕える役職）の盧城部連武彦の子供を妊娠したと、阿閇氏国見に讒言され、無実を晴らすため自殺した事件が雄略天皇紀3年4月条に載っている。
sen.e: According to the History of Emperor Yuryaku April 459 part, Takuhatahime no Himemiko (also called Wakatarashihime no Himemiko; a daughter of the Emperor Yuryaku; Saigu [Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine]) got slandered by Ahe no omi, saying that she got pregnant by a yue (a bathing servant to princes and princesses), Iokibe no Muraji Takehiko, and she killed herself to prove her innocence.
sen.cmt: 「阿閇氏」はウェブでは「阿閇臣」となっており、これで訳出しています。
sen.e: According to the April A.D. 459 part of the History of Emperor Yuryaku, Takuhatahime no Himemiko (also called Wakatarashihime no Himemiko; a daughter of the Emperor Yuryaku; Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine)) got slandered by Ahe no omi, saying that she got pregnant by a yue (a bathing servant to princes and princesses), Iokibe no Muraji Takehiko, and she killed herself to prove her innocence.
sen.cmt: 「雄略天皇紀3年4月条」の訳出しを変更、鍵括弧を小括弧に変更。
sen.e: According to the April A.D. 459 part of the History of Emperor Yuryaku, Takuhatahime no Himemiko (also called Wakatarashihime no Himemiko; a daughter of the Emperor Yuryaku; Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine)) got slandered by Ahe no omi, saying that she got pregnant by a yue (a bathing servant to princes and princesses), Iokibe no Muraji Takehiko, and she killed herself to prove her innocence.

sen.j: 皇女の母である葛城韓媛が父の葛城円大臣から即位前の雄略天皇に、妃として献ぜられたとする記事より約3年後のこととなる。
sen.e: According to this article, this incident happened three years after the princess' mother KATSURAGI no Karahime was offered as a wife to the Emperor Yuryaku (before enthronement) by her father Katsuragi no tsubura no oomi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to this article, this incident happened three years after the princess's mother KATSURAGI no Karahime was offered as a wife to the Emperor Yuryaku (before enthronement) by her father Katsuragi no tsubura no oomi.
sen.cmt: princess’mother をprincess’s motherに記述を変更
sen.e: According to this article, this incident happened three years after the princess's mother KATSURAGI no Karahime was offered as a wife to the Emperor Yuryaku (before enthronement) by her father Katsuragi no tsubura no oomi.

sen.j: 献ぜられる前に韓媛が皇女を産んでいないと年代が合わない。
sen.e: This means that Karahime should have given birth to the princess before getting married to the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This means that Karahime should have given birth to the princess before getting married to the Emperor.
This means that Karahime should have given birth to the princess before getting married to the Emperor.

sen.j: むしろ、上記讒言事件は、外宮の設立と年代が近かったのではないかと推測される。
sen.e: It is more reasonable to suppose that the incident happened as late as around the construction of the Geku.
It is more reasonable to suppose that the incident happened around the time of the construction of the Geku.
sen.cmt: as late as around the construction を around the time of the constructionに変更
sen.e: It is more reasonable to suppose that the incident happened around the time of the construction of the Geku.

sen.j: 尚、阿閇臣国見は、讒言が誤りだと判明した後、伊勢神宮では無く、石上神宮に逃げ込んでいる。
sen.e: After the slander was proven to be false, Ahe no omi fled into the Isonokami-jingu Shrine, not the Ise-jingu Shrine.
After the slander was proven to be false, Ahe no omi fled into the Isonokami-jingu Shrine, not the Ise-jingu Shrine.
After the slander was proven to be false, Ahe no omi fled into the Isonokami-jingu Shrine, not the Ise-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 一種のアジールであったのだろう。
sen.e: The Isonokami-jungu Shrine might have been a kind of an asyl (sanctuary).
The Isonokami-jungu Shrine might have been a kind of an asyl (sanctuary).
The Isonokami-jungu Shrine might have been a kind of an asyl (sanctuary).

sen.j: 先代の安康天皇が、仁徳天皇の子である大草香皇子に、妹の草香幡梭皇女を、同母弟である即位前の雄略天皇の妃に差し出すよう命令した（大草香皇子と草香幡梭皇女は父系の叔父と叔母）。
sen.e: The predecessor the Emperor Anko ordered Imperial Prince Okusaka (a son of the Emperor Nintoku) to offer his younger sister, Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko to the Emperor Yuryaku (before enthronement; younger maternal half-brother of the Emperor Anko) (Imperial Prince Okusaka and Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko are Yuryaku's paternal uncle and aunt, respectively).

The predecessor the Emperor Anko ordered Imperial Prince Okusaka (a son of the Emperor Nintoku) to offer his younger sister, Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko to the Emperor Yuryaku (before enthronement; younger maternal half-brother of the Emperor Anko) (Imperial Prince Okusaka and Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko are Yuryaku's paternal uncle and aunt, respectively).

The predecessor the Emperor Anko ordered Imperial Prince Okusaka (a son of the Emperor Nintoku) to offer his younger sister, Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko to the Emperor Yuryaku (before enthronement; younger maternal half-brother of the Emperor Anko) (Imperial Prince Okusaka and Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko are Yuryaku's paternal uncle and aunt, respectively).

sen.j: 仲介役の坂本臣等の祖である根臣が、大草香皇子の「お受けする」との返答に付けた押木玉鬘（おしきのたまかつら：金銅冠？）を横取りするために、天皇に「大草香皇子は拒否した」と偽りの讒言をする。
sen.e: The agent Ne no Omi (the ancestor of Sakamoto no Omi) made a false remark to the Emperor, saying that the Imperial Prince Okusaka refused the order, in order to pocket the Oshiki no Tamakatsura Crown (made of gold and copper?) that the Imperial Prince Okusaka had trusted to Ne no Omi to show his acceptance.

The agent Ne no Omi (the ancestor of Sakamoto no Omi) made a false remark to the Emperor, saying that the Imperial Prince Okusaka refused the order, in order to pocket the Oshiki no Tamakatsura Crown (made of gold and copper?) that the Imperial Prince Okusaka had trusted to Ne no Omi to show his acceptance.

The agent Ne no Omi (the ancestor of Sakamoto no Omi) made a false remark to the Emperor, saying that the Imperial Prince Okusaka refused the order, in order to pocket the Oshiki no Tamakatsura Crown (made of gold and copper?) that the Imperial Prince Okusaka had trusted to Ne no Omi to show his acceptance.

sen.j: 安康天皇は大草香皇子を殺害、その妃である中蒂姫命（長田大郎女）を奪って自分の皇后とした。
sen.e: The Emperor Anko murdered the Imperial Prince Okusaka and took away the Imperial Prince's wife, Princess Nakashi (Nagata no O Iratsume) as his empress.
The Emperor Anko murdered the Imperial Prince Okusaka and took away the Imperial Prince's wife, Princess Nakashi (Nagata no O Iratsume) as his empress.
The Emperor Anko murdered the Imperial Prince Okusaka and took away the Imperial Prince's wife, Princess Nakashi (Nagata no O Iratsume) as his empress.

sen.j: 中蒂姫は大草香皇子との子である眉輪王を連れていた。
sen.e: The Princess Nakashi brought with her Prince Mayowa, a child between her and the Imperial Prince Okusaka.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Princess Nakashi brought with her Prince Mayowa, a child between her and the Imperial Prince Okusaka.
The Princess Nakashi brought with her Prince Mayowa, a child between her and the Imperial Prince Okusaka.

sen.j: やがて眉輪王に安康天皇は殺害される。
sen.e: Later, Prince Mayowa murdered the Emperor Anko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Later, Prince Mayowa murdered the Emperor Anko.
Later, Prince Mayowa murdered the Emperor Anko.

sen.j: 雄略天皇は草香幡梭皇女に求婚する道の途中で、志貴県主（参考：志貴県主神社）の館が鰹木を上げて皇居に似ていると何癖をつけ、布を掛けた白犬を手に入れる。
sen.e: The Emperor Yuryaku, on his way to propose to Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko, found fault with the house of Shiki no Agatanushi (Shikiagatanushi-jinja Shrine), saying that it looked like the Imperial Palace with Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine) on the top, and obtained a white dog with a cloth on it.

The Emperor Yuryaku, on his way to propose to Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko, found a scene to cavil about at the house of Shiki no Agatanushi (Shikiagatanushi-jinja Shrine), saying that it looked like the Imperial Palace with Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine) on the top, and obtained a white dog with a cloth on it.
sen.cmt: found fault with をfound a scene to cavil about atに変更
sen.e: The Emperor Yuryaku, on his way to propose to Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko, found a scene to cavil about at the house of Shiki no Agatanushi (Shikiagatanushi-jinja Shrine), saying that it looked like the Imperial Palace with Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine) on the top, and obtained a white dog with a cloth on it.

sen.j: それを婚礼のみやげ物にして、草香幡梭皇女を皇后にする。
sen.e: Using the dog as a gift for marriage, he got Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko as his empress.
Using the dog as a gift for marriage, he got Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko as his empress.
Using the dog as a gift for marriage, he got Kusaka no Hatabi no Himemiko as his empress.

sen.j: 以上のように、雄略天皇の皇后、妃は実家が誅された後に決められたものが多い。
sen.e: As shown above, the Emperor Yuryaku often obtained his empress and wives after their parents' homes had been abolished.
As shown above, the Emperor Yuryaku often obtained his empress and wives after their parents' homes had been abolished.
As shown above, the Emperor Yuryaku often obtained his empress and wives after their parents' homes had been abolished.

sen.j: 王権の強化のため、有力皇族や豪族の主を除き、その残党を納得させ、財産を王権に統合するために妃を取るということの様である。
sen.e: His aim was to abolish masters of powerful imperial families and local ruling families to strengthen the imperial power; then to get married to women in those families to integrate the fortune to his own.

His aim was to abolish masters of powerful imperial families and local ruling families and subdue the remnants so as to strengthen the imperial power; then to get married to women in those families to integrate the fortune to his own.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「その残党を納得させ」の部分を追記。
sen.e: His aim was to abolish masters of powerful imperial families and local ruling families and subdue the remnants so as to strengthen the imperial power; then to get married to women in those families to integrate the fortune to his own.

sen.j: 兄である安康天皇の事跡を、雄略天皇が皇族だけでなく、有力豪族（皇族クラスと当時思われていた？）にも拡大適用して行った様に見える。
sen.e: It seems that the Emperor Yuryaku extended what his older brother Emperor Anko did to powerful local ruling families (considered as powerful as imperial families?) as well as imperial families.
It seems that the Emperor Yuryaku extended what his older brother Emperor Anko did to powerful local ruling families (considered as powerful as imperial families?) as well as imperial families.
It seems that the Emperor Yuryaku extended what his older brother Emperor Anko did to powerful local ruling families (considered as powerful as imperial families?) as well as imperial families.

sen.j: 『古事記』では、即位前の雄略天皇に対して、大長谷王（おおはつせのみこ）という表記がたびたび見られる。
sen.e: In the "Kojiki," the Emperor Yuryaku before enthronement is often referred to as Ohatsuse no miko.
In the Kojiki, the Emperor Yuryaku before enthronement is often referred to as Ohatsuse no miko.
In the Kojiki, the Emperor Yuryaku before enthronement is often referred to as Ohatsuse no miko.

sen.j: 通常、即位前の天皇に命（みこと）の称号を用いる『古事記』に於いて、王（みこ）の称号が用いられているのは、異例。
sen.e: This is quite unusual; in the "Kojiki," an emperor before enthronement is usually called mikoto.
This is quite unusual; in the Kojiki, an emperor before enthronement is usually called mikoto.
This is quite unusual; in the Kojiki, an emperor before enthronement is usually called mikoto.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』には、次のようなエピソードがある。
sen.e: The "Nihon Shoki" introduces this episode.
The Nihon Shoki introduces the following episode.
sen.cmt: Nihon Shokiの引用符を削除、this をthe followingに変更。
sen.e: The Nihon Shoki introduces the following episode.

sen.j: 天皇は狩に出かけた際、猪を射殺せない気弱な舎人を殺そうとした。
sen.e: When the Emperor went hunting, he saw a timid toneri (a servant) who could not shoot an arrow to a boar and decided to murder him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When the Emperor went hunting, he saw a timid toneri (a servant) who could not shoot an arrow at a boar and decided to kill him.
sen.cmt: shoot toを shoot atに変更、 murder をkill に変更。
sen.e: When the Emperor went hunting, he saw a timid toneri (a servant) who could not shoot an arrow at a boar and decided to kill him.

sen.j: しかし「陛下、今猪を食したいからといって舎人を斬られますのは、豺狼（山犬・狼のこと）と何も違いません。」と、皇后にいさめられた。
sen.e: However, the Emperor was dissuaded from doing so by the empress, who said, "If you kill this toneri as you want to eat the boar now, there is no distinction between you and a wolf."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the Emperor was dissuaded from doing so by the empress, who said, "If you kill this toneri as you want to eat the boar now, there is no distinction between you and a wolf."
However, the Emperor was dissuaded from doing so by the empress, who said, "If you kill this toneri as you want to eat the boar now, there is no distinction between you and a wolf."

sen.j: 豺狼を残忍なたとえとするのは『後漢書』で登場する。
sen.e: The expression of a wolf as a symbol of cruelty is seen in "Gokanjo" (Historical records of the Later Han Dynasty).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The expression of a wolf as a symbol of cruelty is seen in "Gokanjo" (Historical records of the Later Han Dynasty).
The expression of a wolf as a symbol of cruelty is seen in "Gokanjo" (Historical records of the Later Han Dynasty).

sen.j: そのため話自体が後世の創作とも考えられる。
sen.e: Therefore, this episode might be a fiction made by the posterity.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, this episode might be a fiction made by the posterity.
Therefore, this episode might be a fiction made by the posterity.

sen.j: しかし、雄略天皇の性格をよく表した一節である。
sen.e: At any rate, this episode shows the temper of the Emperor Yuryaku very well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At any rate, this episode shows the temper of the Emperor Yuryaku very well.
At any rate, this episode shows the temper of the Emperor Yuryaku very well.

sen.j: 籠もよ み籠持ち ふくしもよ みぶくし持ち この岳に 菜摘ます児 家聞かん 名告らさね そらみつ 大和の国は おしなべて われこそ居れ しきなべて われこそ座せ 我こそは 告らめ 家をも名をも -『万葉集』巻第一より-
sen.e: Komoyo mikomochi fukushimoyo mibukushimochi konookani natsumasuko iekikan nanorasane soramitsu Yamatonokuni wa oshinabete warekoso ore shikinabete warekoso mase warekoso wa norame iewomo nawomo ("Manyoshu," Volume One)
sen.cmt: 後に現代語訳が続くので、ここは音訳としました。
sen.e: Komoyo mikomochi fukushimoyo mibukushimochi konookani natsumasuko iekikan nanorasane soramitsu Yamatonokuni wa oshinabete warekoso ore shikinabete warekoso mase warekoso wa norame iewomo nawomo ("Manyoshu," Volume One)

Komoyo mikomochi fukushimoyo mibukushimochi konookani natsumasuko iekikan nanorasane soramitsu Yamatonokuni wa oshinabete warekoso ore shikinabete warekoso mase warekoso wa norame iewomo nawomo ("Manyoshu," Volume One)

sen.j: 美しい籠をもち、美しい篦を手に、この丘で菜を摘む娘よ、そなたはどこの家の娘か
sen.e: You the beautiful young woman harvesting vegetable on this hill with a beautiful basket and a beautiful pallet, where are you from?
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: You the beautiful young woman harvesting vegetable on this hill with a beautiful basket and a beautiful pallet, where are you from?
You the beautiful young woman harvesting vegetable on this hill with a beautiful basket and a beautiful pallet, where are you from?

sen.j: 名はなんというのか
sen.e: What is your name?
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: What is your name?
What is your name?

sen.j: この大和の国を、隅々まで治めている、全てを支配しているこの私から、名をも家をも名乗ろう
sen.e: I myself will tell you who I am, where I am from, although I govern this Yamato Province and the whole of this world.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: I myself will tell you who I am, where I am from, although I govern this Yamato Province and the whole of this world.
I myself will tell you who I am, where I am from, although I govern this Yamato Province and the whole of this world.

sen.j: 夕されば 小倉の山に 鳴く鹿は こよひは鳴かず 寝ねにけらしも -『万葉集』巻第九より-
sen.e: Yusareba Ogurano yamani nakushika wa koyoiwa nakazu nenenikerashimo ("Manyoshu," Volume Nine)
sen.cmt: 後に現代語訳が続くので、ここは音訳としました。
sen.e: Yusareba Ogurano yamani nakushika wa koyoiwa nakazu nenenikerashimo ("Manyoshu," Volume Nine)
Yusareba Ogurano yamani nakushika wa koyoiwa nakazu nenenikerashimo ("Manyoshu," Volume Nine)

sen.j: 夕方になると、いつも小倉山で鳴く鹿が、今夜は鳴かない。
sen.e: Every evening, deer in Mt. Ogura cry, but tonight, they do not cry.
Every evening, deer in Mt. Ogura cry, but tonight, they do not cry.
Every evening, deer in Mt. Ogura cry, but tonight, they do not cry.

sen.j: もう寝てしまったらしいよ。
sen.e: They seem to have gone asleep already.
They seem to have gone asleep already.
They seem to have gone asleep already.

sen.j: ※舒明天皇作とも。
sen.e: Some records say that this poem was made by the Emperor Jomei.
Some records say that this poem was made by the Emperor Jomei.
Some records say that this poem was made by the Emperor Jomei.

tit.j: 在位年と西暦との対照表
tit.e: Chronological table of his reign shown in the western calendar
Chronological table of his reign shown in the western calendar
Chronological table of his reign shown in the western calendar
